question: The diagrams below show how houses can be protected in areas which are prone to flooding.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The schemes compare two different methods of defence for homes that can be easily affected by floods. Overall, they show flood protection with and without a stopbank, while the at-risk home is raised higher above ground level in two pictures.The first diagram depicts how a stopbank acts as a natural barrier to prevent river water from flooding. The stopbank is a small mound of land next to the river that is higher than the 100-year-flood level and prevents the drain from overwhelming its banks. Nearby buildings can be built on stilts to prevent flooding from rainwater as well as the water passing through the floodgate beneath the stopbank, resulting in an area of ‘internal ponding.’If it had not been a stopbank, as described in the second diagram, there would have been nothing to stop the river from flooding. In this case, the solution is to put homes on stilts much higher than the one in the first picture. The height of the stilts is measured to ensure that the floor of the house is three hundred meters above the 100-year-flood level regardless of how deep the water area is under the house. This measure is called the ‘freeboard.’
llm: This is a sketch of a conventional house that is on the ground floor and exposed directly to the water. This design offers limited protection as floodwaters can easily damage the foundations and the house itself. The second diagram, on the other hand, is a design for an elevated house that is built above the flood level. This design has columns, which allow water to flow under the building and reduce the damage to the foundations and lower living areas. The equipment and wiring that is installed on this floor are also vulnerable to damage by water, which can cause additional safety risks and costs in the event of flooding. Both diagrams offer different ways of dealing with the danger of flooding, but the solution that is the best option is to raise the house. Not only does this prevent damage to the building, but it also raises the essentials such as wiring and heating out of the water. The design also includes a sloped courtyard to direct water away from the house, which also increases flood resilience. This solution also allows people to recover after flooding as it reduces the cost of repairs and reduces the time to return to normal life. In conclusion, the diagrams show the stark difference between a conventional and elevated house in flood-prone areas. The first offers limited protection against flooding and is less resilient, while the second offers a more advanced approach to a safe and resilient structure. The second option can serve as a model for future developments in similar environments.

question: The diagrams below show the design for a wave-energy machine and its location.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: first of all, the picture show (A Wave- energy machine) we can see that there is electricity generator its the machine that take the energy from the waves and it contain two turbines so the air could flow throuh it and from what it shown we can notice that there is two of wave energy machin: the large waves and the small waves.Secondly,the small wavs had low output since its for the small waves, in addition it also had low installation costs because its smaller.in the other hand the large waves had high output and high installation costs since its also large.To sum up we can say that the air flow to the turbine so the turbine could move and got the electrisity , there is also air come from the water levels which hepls the machine get the elecricity that it needs so the people could use it like a solar power.
llm: The wave-energy machine converts the kinetic energy of waves into electricity. The diagrams show the structure of the machine and its location. The machine consists of two chambers. The chambers are placed under the water surface and waves come into the lower chamber. The rising water level pushes air out of the upper chamber and a water pump drives a generator to generate electricity. The diagrams also show the effects of the environment on the design. The site is strategically placed along the coast where prevailing waves run. The machine is firmly fixed to the seabed and can be used for a long time. The waves are changed into electricity by the carefully designed machine that combines the effects of its structure and its location. The machine is placed in a place where the waves are stable and does not interfere with the balance of the environment. The balance between energy production and conservation is very important, because the balance of marine life is necessary for the diversity of life. The balance between energy efficiency and conservation is a great advantage, and this technology is a promising way to develop coastal areas.

question: The diagrams below show the development of the horse over a period of 40 million years.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant
human: The diagram depicts the different stages of the body habitus and the relative changes in foot structures that under went in the process of evolution of the modern horse, since 40 million years ago.The modern horse had gone through 3 main stages in order to become it's current version, each stage shows distinctive changes in the body as a whole.Having said that, the earliest species that existed is namely Echippus, then it was mesohippus and finally it was Merychippus.The Echippus is the identified first ancestor of the modern horse that existed 40 million years ago. They appeared relatively similar to the size of a sheep and their foot apearently had four toes.However, Mesohippus was the second in line of the modern horses and was relatively bigger and taller, the foot structure got limited to three toes and the middle toe being the widerest.15 million years after the existance of mesohippus, merychippus emerged, they were similar in both the size and shape of our modern horses, but as far as the foot is concerned the middle toe became more prominent and the rest two toes started to shrink. Finally, the modern horses look twice the size of Echippus and their feet looked proper coronet.
llm: The earliest horse, Eohippus, was about 40 million years old. Its most developed form was mesohippus, which developed into the modern horse, Equus. When the climate changed and the meadows began to appear about 20 million years ago, Mesohippus appeared. This small, dog-sized animal had a large head, an arched back and four toes on each foot, showing that it lived mainly in woods where agility was necessary for moving through the thickets. Its teeth were adapted to a diet of soft grass and leaves, reflecting the fact that it was herbivorous and lived in a green environment. The molars were also more complex, indicating that its diet was changing to a more resistant grass, and the animal adapted to a more open landscape. This intermediate form was larger than the eohippus, its legs were longer and its body was longer, making it faster. Mesohippus not only benefited from its ability to move fast and economically on the plains, but also thrived in a grassland environment. The horse developed further, about 2 million years ago, into the modern horse. This is illustrated by the shift from a small, many-toed animal to a large, single-toed grazer, which shows the significant biological and physiological changes that took place, and demonstrates the flexibility and adaptability of the horse through its history. In conclusion, the horse shows a remarkable adaptation to changing environments over millions of years.

question: The diagrams below show the existing ground floor plan of a house and a proposed plan for some building work.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The information below shows the present floor plan and changes been suggested. Generally spekaing, there is no big difference, kitchen will stay as a kitchen and living room will stay as a living room.At the moment the living room space is smaller than in proposed new plan. The living room space suggested to be increased as internal wall will be demolited. Moreover, in suggested plan there is no place for storage under the stairs as stairs will be changed in their shape and also there will be no more hall place will be integrated into living room.The door intro kitchen will be switched from single one to double and will be located near the entrance door. The kitchen furniture suggested to be located on the opposite side to the wall and doubled indoor door. However, some things stays the same in both plans. For example, the location of both entrance doors - front and backyard and also wall between hall and kitchen.
llm: The ground floor of the existing plan consists of a living room, a dining room, a kitchen and a small passage leading to the staircase. The proposed plan consists of the same rooms but with some changes intended to optimize space and increase functionality. This layout, although eminently practical, is slightly compartmentalized and there is no obvious relationship between the rooms. The living room occupies the whole of the front part of the house. The dining room, situated just behind the living room, leads into the kitchen. This change illustrates a trend towards open-plan living and a greater sense of openness between the different areas of the house. In the proposed plan the living room has been extended into the dining room, thereby increasing the available space and the inviting character of the room. Next, a new utility room has been added next to the kitchen, which increases the functionality of the kitchen by providing a separate area for washing up and storage. The dining room, in its new position at the back of the house, will enjoy more natural light and have a better view of the garden, thus improving the dining experience. The proposed changes thus illustrate a modern preference for open space and practicality in the home. In summary, the proposed alterations will convert the ground floor of the house from a compartmentalized layout into an open, spacious arrangement that will allow for better interaction between the rooms. The utility room will make for a more efficient and pleasant living experience.

question: The diagrams below show the water supply system in Australia present and in future.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The given diagram illustrates the processes involved in the water supply system in Australia at the present and in the future.To begin, the first kind of water is located in the dam and storage where the waste water is lead to a water treatment plant. Meanwhile, from the storage come out pure water and provide potable water to households, factories, shops, and all the city. At the same time, the wastewater produced in the city is transferred to a water treatment plant as well.The last type of water is the storm water that is sent to the river from the city.Overall, it can be seen that the process has three types of waters in the process of water supply which are pure, storm, and waste water. depending on the type of water, these can be found in the dam and storage, water treatment plant, river and in different places of the city such as households, factories, shops, among others.
llm: Presently, Australia's water supply is provided by a combination of rivers, dams, and reservoirs supplemented by industrial and domestic water treatment facilities. This system suffers considerable strain because of the variability of rainfall, which causes droughts and surpluses. The proposed future water supply system is an evolution of the present system. Presently water is drawn from natural sources, treated, and then distributed to towns and cities, resulting in the evaporation of water from open reservoirs and the high cost of transporting water over long distances. Leakage from old pipes further increases the problem of water management. Presently, water supply relies on large open reservoirs. In contrast, the proposed future water supply system involves the implementation of advanced water treatment and recovery methods, such as rainwater harvesting, and desalination plants which are powered by renewable energy sources. In addition, the future system integrates smart technology, such as the Internet of Things (IoT) for the monitoring of water usage and quality. This is to ensure that there is less water waste and greater water efficiency. In conclusion, the proposed future water supply system reflects an increasing awareness of the environment and the need for sustainable resource management. With the increasing demand for water and with a growing population, the aim is not only to secure water supplies for future generations but also to ensure that the water supply system is resilient to future changes in technology.

question: The diagrams show the structure of solar panel and its use.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The diagram illustrates how a solar panel is constructed, and the complex process of how the renewable energy source provides heated water and air to households.The first diagram shows us visual information about the basic structure of the solar panel. It´s construction is mainly a large box with two pipes placed on both sides. Then, one equally large top which is transparent is placed on top of the container.According to the second diagram, the solar panel is designed to provide the home with warm air. Firstly, cold air is allowed in through the inlet and let inside the box. Secondly, the transparent top allows sunrays to transform the cool air to warm air by their heating properties. After that, the warm air goes through and out the outlet.In regards to the third diagram, we can clearly see that the construction is similar with the exception that water pipes are added in the main box, in order to supply households with hot water. In comparison with the second diagram, where air was driven through the pipes, water is the main resource here. After the water has entered the inlet, water passes through the pipes and out
llm: In the heart of a solar panel, there are photovoltaic cells, which are usually made of silicon. A solar panel is fundamentally made up of several important parts, which work together to produce solar energy. The diagrams show the structure of a solar panel and how it works, explaining how the sunlight is converted into electrical energy. Below the cells, there is a waterproof backing layer, which provides structure, and prevents the cells from getting wet, ensuring their long life. These cells convert sunlight directly into electricity by the photovoltaic effect. In addition, additional components, such as box and mounting brackets, provide greater functionality and improve installation. Then the converted electrical energy is carried by the electrical circuits to the inverter, a key component in the system, which converts direct current into alternating current, which is used in households and industry. A solar panel’s practical use is not limited to electricity production. The box ensures the electrical connections are made properly, ensuring safe and efficient operation. The mounting brackets ensure that the panel is installed on a roof or on a frame, where it can receive the maximum amount of sunlight. It can be used to power private houses, commercial buildings and even large-scale grids. Their installation not only ensures greater energy independence, but also ensures a more sustainable environment. They significantly reduce the carbon footprint, which makes it possible to meet the needs of our energy supplies in a sustainable way. It is a great step forward in the development of solar energy, and the diagrams clearly show its structure and the way it works.

question: The education system is the only critical factor in the development of a country, agree/disagree (from Target Band
human: This essay was written on a topic from “Target Band 7” book (page 54, reprinted with permission).You should spend about 40 minutes on this taskSome people say that the education system is the only critical factor in the development of a country. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Write at least 250 wordsEducation plays an imperative role in the overall progression of a country. Many people may heavily rely on quality education as preparation for real life employment and experiences. However, there are other factors that are needed to propel a country towards success.We must acknowledge the way the education system of a country prepares most individuals by equipping them with various skills. Prior to gaining a qualification to practice certain professions such as teaching, nursing or accounting, it is necessary for the individuals to undergo rigorous training. Certificate and diploma programs as well as university degrees are good examples of that. Some graduates may even choose to pursue further studies to attain certain requirements to be able to practice their chosen profession.The education system is undoubtedly important in preparing individuals to take on roles leading to the development of a country. However, it seems that producing graduates alone isn’t a guarantee of the advancement of a country. There are other factors that should come into play, and motivation of individuals is one. Without motivation, people may lose track of what they intend to do to contribute to the improvement of a country. drives people to achieve and maximize their potentials, because they are determined to get better at many aspects of their life, eventually yielding improvement for their entire country.Furthermore, the availability of natural resources and job opportunities may also affect the growth of a national economy. Innovations of many individuals require raw materials, and should the country be able to mine these, their production and perhaps even export may help in stabilizing the local market. Finally, it is also important that the availability of employment is aligned with the skills of individuals applying for the positions. Giving skilled people the opportunity to apply their knowledge and experience in their profession makes them more productive, which contributes to GDP growth.In conclusion, education continues to play a pivotal role in the development of a country. However, other important factors should play a role in order to achieve steady and continuous progress.This response adequately addresses the task prompt. The writer’s viewpoint is clear throughout the essay. Each paragraph has its role and they are used effectively to organise ideas and information. The coherence and advanced vocabulary help the writer to create an impression of a skilled, fluent English user. Good control of grammar and punctuation is evident. This essay could achieve Band 8 in IELTS.
llm: the following task) . A strong education system is essential for the development of a skilled workforce. Education plays an important role in promoting economic growth, social cohesion and innovation. And more than that, education teaches people critical thinking and problem-solving skills, which they can then apply to address complex societal issues. The countries where people have higher levels of education generally have higher economic productivity. This is mainly because the economic policies, transport and communication systems, political stability, and natural resources of the country also play a key role in the development of a country. However, it is not possible to single out education as the only critical factor in a country's development. Culture and social equality also play an important role in the development of a country. It is not surprising that the development of a country such as Singapore is related to the presence of a strong government and a strong education system. The role of education in the development of a country can be reduced to a single factor. This is because, for example, a society that values equality will realize the benefits of a good education system. The interaction between these factors is what shapes the development of a country. The most complete development requires a multi-pronged approach involving the economic, political and social dimensions.

question: The end of the world’s fossil fuel resources and the subsequent changes will be a positive development in society. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: Today’s society overwhelmingly depends on products made from fossil fuels. Most people would initially think about fuel for transport, but of course, fossil fuels are part of most of the fabric of life around us, from the plastics on our furniture to the pavements that we walk on. Changing our reliance on these resources can have various consequences; however, I believe that overall the society will benefit from finding viable alternatives for them.Depending on whether eco-friendly alternatives are developed, the positive effect on transport and the reduction of the associated pollution will be significant. Exhaust fumes from motor vehicles, planes and ships decrease air quality and contribute to global warming and the greenhouse effect. People’s health and the health of the planet will surely improve without these industries relying on fossil fuels. It could be that a type of transport crisis could develop as a result if society can no longer provide the power to transport so many individuals to where they want to go. This, however, does not have to be a bad thing, as it could force society to use alternative solutions, such as transport sharing and public transport development. The change in mind set has already begun. Some countries have already committed to having fossil fuel free transport and more cities are banning private vehicles from the centre of cities.Another positive development would be that more time and money would have to be put into developing renewable sources of energy, such as wind power, solar power, hydropower and tidal power. Technologies would improve and be more efficient and again, the world would use fewer sources of energy that cause pollution. This development can also be seen today, with many governments committing to proportions of their power needs coming from renewable resources.I, therefore, strongly agree with the statement that the changes from reducing reliance on fossil fuels will be positive. The only caveat is that society will need to have developed alternative sources of power rather soon, in order to avoid an energy crisis.
llm: First of all, the end of fossil fuels can stimulate the development of new energy technology. On the one hand, it could be a positive step towards a sustainable society, while on the other hand, this transition could be a serious challenge. These changes could reduce the world's carbon dioxide emissions and lead to more energy independence for the countries that use them. In countries such as Denmark, for example, wind energy is being used so much that it already accounts for a large share of their electricity consumption. The decrease in the supply of fossil fuels can also cause an increase in the awareness of climate change and the need for a more sustainable way of life. In cities, for example, public transport, pedestrianization and horticulture will play an increasingly important role. Many people work in the fossil fuel industry all over the world and a rapid transition away from these resources could lead to high unemployment and economic unrest. Fortunately, however, this transition is not always without its negative consequences, because, for example, New York City's bike lanes and urban gardens show how cities can change for the better. Balance these different aspects of society and you will find out how far the inevitable changes benefit society. Finally, the transition to the use of renewable energy is not yet fully developed, which could result in energy shortages and energy imbalances during the transition period.

question: The fact that enormous sums are paid for pieces of art is not acceptable at a time when many people around the world live in poverty. Discuss this statement and give your opinion.Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It is true that pieces of art in today’s world can change hands for enormous sums. Works by artists such as Picasso, da Vinci and Rembrandt have been sold for millions of dollars. Recently, a Modigliani was sold to a billionaire for one hundred and seventy million dollars. It certainly seems obscene that such figures are spent when many people around the world live in poverty.The work of many charities would be transformed by the money generated by just one of these art sales and in turn, the lives of ordinary people in need would be transformed. Medicines, food and shelter amongst other things could easily be provided, saving lots of lives, many of which would be children. When the issue is looked at from this point of view, the art sales world certainly seems obscene.However, in my opinion, things are unlikely to change. Human greed is endemic and people who have the drive to earn that amount of money and who actually have access to these sums in cash are not often people who will part with their wealth. Lots of prosperous people support many charities, but it is unlikely that they would completely relinquish their access to the luxuries that accompany their lives. The works of art are also often seen as investments in themselves, to be held on to for a period of time and then resold at a profit.In conclusion, in an ideal world, the vast sums of money that are spent on fine and rare works of art would be better spent on helping those in need. In reality, however, this is unlikely to take place.
llm: Art is the essence of culture, history and human experience. However, art can be auctioned for millions, while many people say that these resources would be much better used to alleviate suffering and help the poor. The question of whether to spend so much money on art against the background of world poverty is an ethical one. Is it right to spend money on art? On the one hand, those who support the high art market argue that art plays an important role in society and enriches it culturally. For example, art lovers annually attract millions of tourists to Paris and Florence, which in turn contributes to the economy of these cities. But many people consider such spending a contradiction and a denial of human dignity. On the other hand, the contrasting relationship between the millions spent on art and the suffering of millions of people who live in poverty is too obvious. In addition, art is a tool for exposing social injustices and poverty itself. The resources used in the art market could be used to provide education, health care and food security for those in need. According to the World Bank, nine percent of the world's population lives on less than two dollars a day. Using these data, one must ask what is the most important thing in the world and what society considers valuable. With an equitable distribution of resources and more philanthropic spending in the field of art, it is possible to achieve a more just and caring society. In conclusion, while the high value of art shows its significance for society and culture, a balance must be found between art appreciation and the urgent need to eradicate poverty.

llm: The first chart shows that the total amount spent by parents on their children’s sports has significantly increased during the given period. The second chart shows that the total number of children who took part in the three sports was 812,084 for swimming, 862,962 for football and 917,259 for tennis. From this, it can be seen that football was the most popular during this period. The number of children participating in this sport began at around 700,000 in 2008, but, despite some fluctuations, reached a peak of around 950,000 in 2014. These numbers may indicate an increasing awareness of the importance of sports for the health and well-being of children. Parents are investing more money in the sport, but in the same period, the numbers of children taking part have varied, particularly in football, which has been a major sport in the UK for a long time. The figures for swimming, on the other hand, were fairly stable, beginning at around 400,000 children and gradually increasing to around 500,000 by the end of the period. Tennis, on the other hand, showed a significant decrease, beginning at around 200,000 and falling to about 150,000 in 2014. In conclusion, the information shows a clear trend in the increasing amount of money spent on sports by British parents and the rising number of children who play football, but the sport of tennis is in decline. While football is more popular, judging by the numbers, its popularity has remained stable, while tennis is waning.

question: The first chart below shows the percentages of women and men in a country involved in some kinds of home tasks (cooking, cleaning, pet caring and repairing the house. The second chart shows the amount of time each gender spent on each task per day.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The two given charts illustrates the houshold work done by male and female of a nation. where firstly, the amount of work done by men and women is measured in percentage, and secondly, the average time devoted to do perform those work is calculated in minutes.Overall, it can be clearly seen that women performed more tasks in both the given terms then men, Although, men performed House repairs more than women.Firstly, women performed more household work than men, their main interest was in cooking and cleaning, where 80% of women performed Cooking and 60 percent cleaning, where men were 20% less in both the tasks. However, they were equal in pet care, Although men spend close to 20 min minutes in house repair on average basis.
llm: Women are more involved in all four categories - cooking, cleaning, pet care and repairing the house. For cooking, women spend more time than men, almost 80% to 40%. For cleaning, the percentage of women is 75%, and the percentage of men is 30%. Pet care is a similar pattern, with women at about 50% and men at about 20%. However, the biggest difference is that only about 25% of women and 60% of men participate in repairs. Women cook for about an hour and a half every day, while men only spend about thirty minutes. The two-hour daily cleaning and cooking time is similar. In terms of pet care, women spend about an hour, while men spend only twenty minutes. However, the most prominent feature of the first table is that women are more involved in most housework, and they spend more time than men. However, the men are far more involved in house repairs, spending an hour and a half a day, while women spend only half an hour. These differences show that there is still a clear division of domestic labor between the sexes. However, men are more prone to participate in repairs, which is consistent with the existing gender role.

llm: A variety of motives for traveling abroad are shown in the first chart. The most common motive for traveling abroad during this period was for recreation, with a large majority of respondents citing vacation as their reason for traveling abroad. Business was also a significant motive, illustrating the growing internationalization of industry. The second largest motive was visiting relatives and friends, indicating the enduring importance of personal relationships in motivating travel. The increasing leisure time and disposable income available to people during the mid-nineties may be seen as the result of a recovering economy. There was also an increasing interest in North America and Asia, a reflection of the increasing importance of these regions in the late nineties. The second chart shows the destinations of these travelers. The chart shows that Europe remained the most popular destination, particularly for leisure travelers, presumably because of the rich cultural heritage, historical sites and cultural experiences to be found there. question: The flow chart below shows an automatic photo booth. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The automatic photo booth allows you to take photos of yourself by self-service. Insert sufficient amount of coins and choose colour or black & white at the panel. You are allowed to select 1 large format or 4 password-sized photos, but remember that if you use the photos in your passport, it has to be a colour one.In the photo-taking area, there is a circle-shaped chair with an adjustable stool. Be seated if you are ready for the shot. Sit straight and wait for light signal flash after 3 seconds. After the shot, the photo will be delivered and available on the slot near the coin panel within 60 seconds.
llm: In the flow chart, the first step is to select the type of photograph, which may be either a traditional portrait or a funny picture. This selection is the beginning of the whole experience and emphasizes individuality. After payment, the customer will be directed to the location where the photo will be taken. After the selection is made, payment is required. The diagram shows that the customer can pay with different payment methods, such as cash and credit cards, which offers the customer convenience and flexibility. Following the picture, the image will be processed and manipulated to give the best result. This step also includes the possibility of adjusting the background and the light to ensure the best possible result. The diagram is designed to be easy to use for people of all ages. It also offers flexibility and individuality because the customer can influence the photo process at several points. Afterwards the customer can print the photo or save it digitally, which makes it possible to satisfy various preferences. The photo booth is a modern solution that combines simplicity with personalization. The booth is also efficient, as shown by the smooth transitions from selection to payment, from picture to print, which shows a good combination of technology and everyday life.

question: The flow chart illustrates the consequence of deforestation. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The supplied illustration outlines the problems of cutting forests. As we can see, there are 4 main branches and each of them describes a certain issue, caused by deforestation.According to the first branch from the left, forest destruction can lead to the state when soil becomes hard and "baked". It occurs due to the fact that heavy logging equipment compresses the soil, as the first block of the chart says. Because soil becomes "baked", rain water starts to run off which causes flooding.If we look at the remaining branches, we can see that they all lead to the same conclusion - less biodiversity. But there are three different reasons for it. The first one is soil erosion. When we cut the trees, we have fewer tree roots to support the topsoil that eventually erodes.The second reason - increased risk of burning. It is followed by the destruction of waste wood. Then we have some micro-organisms such as pioneer species that move in and initiate degradation of vegetation. And it's all resulted in less biodiversity.The last branch starts with the fact that after cutting forests we have less plants to give back moisture to air, so less moisture enters the air. This triggers less precipitation, and so, increased droughts. Plants that unable to withstand hot and dry weather die and it ends with less biodiversity.To conclude everything, the main purpose of the presented flow chart was to demonstrate the severe damage that could be caused by deforestation.
llm: The initial consequence of deforestation is the disappearance of habitat for many species of animals and disrupts the functioning of the whole forest ecosystem. From this initial consequence a whole series of consequences follows. This directly affects the food web, and as more and more species become extinct, the functioning of the whole system is disturbed even more. The most significant result of this is the decrease in the diversity of species. Deforestation also affects the course of climate change, as trees are an important source of carbon dioxide and the removal of trees contributes to the increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide. As a result, the global warming accelerates, and the weather becomes more extreme. The next consequence of deforestation is the deterioration of the soil, which also contributes to the increase in soil erosion, and, as a result of the loss of arable land, the number of cultivated fields decreases and the yield of agriculture decreases. In conclusion, the flowchart briefly demonstrates the multifaceted consequences of deforestation, and shows how it disrupts the functioning of the whole forest system, reduces the diversity of species, accelerates climate change, depletes the quality of the soil, and finally affects human societies. The flowchart also shows that deforestation affects human populations, especially those that depend on forests for their livelihoods, and, as resources decline, people are faced with unemployment, relocation, and the loss of cultural identity. A rapid and sustainable solution to deforestation is therefore a necessary part of a balanced, sustainable development of human societies.

This gap shows a growing gap between the country's energy needs and domestic production capacity. Moving into the 1990s, the gap between energy production and consumption became more obvious, and in 2000, energy consumption reached around 100 quadrillion BTU, while energy production only reached 75 quadrillion BTU. The prediction for 2025 predicts a continued increase in energy consumption, and consumption will reach 120 quadrillion BTU, while production will rise slightly to 85 quadrillion BTU. It shows that unless new energy policies and technology are implemented, the United States will face increasing challenges in the sustainable use of energy, its dependence on foreign resources and the possibility of future energy security problems. Waterloo comes in a close second, due to its central location, near tourist and business attractions and to the close proximity of the Bank of England. Moreover, the graph also shows noticeable peaks during the weekdays, especially during the morning and evening rush hours, which corresponds to the daily commute of London’s workforce, as the Underground is used to transport them to and from work. This shows the difference between the accessibility and convenience of the stations, and thus the number of passengers they attract. Accordingly, a clearer picture can be seen, enabling us to determine how to improve the system, so as to be more efficient and more in tune with the needs of the passengers. Finally, a noticeable dip in the weekday numbers, a drop that is not seen on the weekend, suggests that leisure travellers behave in a different way to the working population.

llm: From the data, it is evident that overseas enrolments in Australian universities increased during the decade, beginning at approximately 150,000 in the early years and rising to over 400,000 at the end of the period, an increase of over 160%. The increase can be attributed to Australia’s reputation as an ideal place for international students to study because of its high-quality institutions, diverse programs and its multicultural environment. The local enrolments, on the other hand, began at just over 600,000, peaking at approximately 650,000 and then falling to just under 600,000 at the end of the decade. The increase in overseas enrolments is particularly prominent in the second half of the decade. It indicates an upward trend which can be attributed to the international marketing strategies and the growing importance of higher education in the world. Local enrolments, on the other hand, represent the vast majority of the students. This trend may indicate a number of factors, such as changes in the demography, socioeconomic factors influencing the students’ decision to study, and a change in the market structure. In summary, the trends indicate a notable divergence between the increase in overseas enrolments and the stagnant trend of local enrolments in Australian universities. This demonstrates a dynamic change in the educational system, highlighting the importance of adjusting strategies to retain local students while accommodating the increasing demand from overseas students.

question: The graphs below show the number of men and women in full and part-time employment in Australia between 1973 and 1993.Write a report for a university lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The graphs compare the participation of full-time and part-time workers in Australia as differenciated by gender and age group in the period betweeen 1973 and 1993.Overall, it is clearly seen that the number of full-time workers for both male and female experienced a slight decline as part-time work become more favourable among these employees. llm: This data clearly reveals the changing roles of women and men in the Australian workforce. It is worth noting that the figures distinguish between full-time and part-time work, which allows us to see clearly the changing role of women and men in the workforce over the two decades under review. In 1973 there were approximately 2.3 million men employed full-time, whereas in 1993 this figure had fallen to around 1.8 million. This shows a notable trend in the decline of full-time employment for men. On the other hand, the number of women employed full-time has more than doubled from about 0.4 million in 1973 to about 1.0 million in 1993. In contrast, the graphs show that the number of women working part-time has risen dramatically from around 1.3 million in 1973 to about 3.1 million in 1993. This increase reflects the changing social attitudes to women’s roles in the workplace and their increasing involvement in paid employment. As for men, the figures for part-time employment have remained relatively stable over the period in question, fluctuating between approximately 0.5 and 0.7 million. This illustrates the view that part-time work was less desirable for men, who traditionally preferred full-time positions. This increase may be partly explained by an increased acceptance of flexible working arrangements, which is probably due to the fact that women have traditionally played a dual role as primary carer and worker. This breakdown of the traditional gender roles indicates a broader change in society, which will continue to have an effect on the workforce in the future. In conclusion, the data show a significant change in the roles of men and women in the Australian workforce between 1973 and 1993.

question: The illustrations show two stages in the development of the mobile phone. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.You should write at least 150 words.

As the above shows, mobile phones have moved from a basic communication tool to an advanced technological device. question: The line graph below shows the oil production and consumption in China between 1982 and 2006.Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: This line graph indicates oil production and consumption per day in China from 1982 to 2006. Clearly, the consumption doubled its production in 2006.To begin with, oil consumption started the millions of oil barrels per day for almost two, and remained the same by 1990. But, its consumption suddenly surged to about 3.7 million in 1994. Then, the number of consumption skyrocketed from 1998 and reached a peak of more than 6 million in 2006. Consequently, the consumption tripled, compared with 1982.Secondly, the production also commenced the millions of oil barrels per day around two, and increased its production to three million in 1986. In contrast, its production leveled off by 1994. Afterward, the production slightly kept going up and resulted in 3.5 million in 2006. As a result, the oil production increased, compared with 1982. But it is clear that the pace of production is quite slower than consumption.
llm: The line graph of the oil production and consumption in China from 1982 to 2006 shows that the production was about 2 million barrels per day in the first year and the consumption was about 1.5 million barrels per day, so the total is more than the consumption. This is a small surplus, which may be an indicator of the developing economy at that time. But in the next year, the production increased gradually, and by the end of the year, the consumption exceeded the production, indicating that the country's energy consumption has increased sharply, which is probably due to the reform and development of China's economy. From 1982 to the middle of 1993, China's oil production was still rising, and the total was around 4 million barrels per day, indicating that the total energy consumption in China had been increasing, and this is the result of China's economic reform and development during this period. Then, after 1993, China's oil production and consumption were no longer in harmony, and the production gradually decreased, and the total was about 5 million barrels per day in 2006. However, the consumption was still rising, and the total consumption was more than 6 million barrels per day. The overall trend is that China's oil consumption has been rising, and the production has not been enough to meet the huge energy needs of the country, so China has relied heavily on oil imports. The situation not only reflects China's rapid economic development, but also China's vulnerability to the international oil market. At the end of the year, the gap between oil production and oil consumption was still large, and China urgently needed to meet the energy needs of the country. The next step of China's economic and environmental policy is to consider the development of China's energy and environment.

question: The maps below show the development of a small fishing village and its surrounding area into a large European tourist resort.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The map illustrates on how a fishing village with a population of 12,000 people in 1974 has been converted to a European tourist resort in 2004 which can accommodate 80,000 residents and 50,000 tourist beds.Except for the fishing village, all other places were modified.It is apparent from the map that there has been a huge loss of flora and fauna on this restructure. For survival, fishermen would have taken up jobs like working in tourist shops, serving tourists at restaurant and guiding tourists.
llm: At first, the fishing village was a small rural village with a few houses clustered near the shore, a fish market, and a road out of the village. The surrounding area was predominantly rural, with agriculture and natural vegetation dominating the landscape. The changes in the layout, buildings, and surroundings are evident. The village was transformed into a tourist resort, with hotels, restaurants, and various entertainments. The village was isolated, offering little service for visitors. Furthermore, the old road was replaced by a highway that connected the village with nearby cities and tourist destinations. The highway not only improved access to the resort, but also showed urban planning with a view to accommodating increasing tourist numbers. The change from a quiet fishing economy to a bustling tourist industry with the help of tourist industry is evident. The main emphasis of the resort is leisure. The development of the resort is evidenced by significant changes in transport and land use, and a shift towards a more diverse economy that capitalizes on the picturesque coastal setting for mass tourism. The natural beauty of the coast has been preserved, but complemented by man-made entertainments that enhance the experience of visitors. The emergence of a tourist economy also reveals the changes in the local economy and the community’s sense of identity. This has also created new opportunities and problems.

question: The movement of people from the countryside into the cities is happening in many parts of the world, resulting in the problems, especially in cities.What are the causes of this movement, and how can it be reversedGive reasons for your answer, and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: People move from the countryside into the cities. It occurs in many parts of the world, causing problems, especially in urban areas. This essay will elaborate on the causes of this movement, and the way it can be reversed from my personal standpoint.Centralization has caused this movement. All the major institutions and facilities are in the cities. Thus, people in rural areas have to sacrifice considerable time and effort to travel to urban centres. As it is also costly, people choose to move into the cities so that traveling does not consume their time. For instance, one-fifth of the total population in Korea currently lives in Seoul, the capital city of Korea. In fact, all the educational, medical, and entertainment facilities are centralized in urban areas. It can be reserved by implementing decentralization. The government has to disperse the location of the major institutions and diverse types of facilities into different districts so that people living in remote areas can also benefit.Furthermore, people in remote areas want to earn opportunities for better employment or education. As a city is a point where technologies, investments ,and professions gather, there is a better opportunity for people to get employed or educated in a improved quality. Therefore, people choose to leave the countryside. Thereby, the government can initiate the policies in which firms earn benefit when they move their head office to districts. If the firms commence moving, it will produce a great amount of employment.Conclusively, not only the government but also the businesses and institutions have to co-operate to combat problems resulting from a surge in the movement of people from the countryside into the cities.
llm: The movement of people from the countryside into the city, known as urbanization, is occurring at an unprecedented rate in many parts of the world. This movement, fueled by various reasons, has become a major challenge for cities. For example, young people, often young people, migrated to cities to get an education and to achieve career growth, abandoning agriculture, which is no longer profitable. In addition, urban areas generally have a better living standard, better health care, better education, and better entertainment. But the increasing population of cities causes problems such as overcrowded housing, congestion, and overloaded public services. The hope of improving the quality of life and achieving social mobility also makes people leave the countryside. In order to avoid urbanization-related problems, steps should be taken to persuade people to stay in rural areas. This can be achieved by investing in local businesses to create jobs for the younger generation and making rural economies more prosperous. One way to do this is to improve the living conditions in rural areas by investing in the development of rural areas, such as better transport, health care and education. Lastly, by making rural life viable and desirable, the trend of urban migration can be reversed. The global pandemic of the COV19 virus has shown that many people have been able to work from anywhere, and even live in rural areas while working in urban industries. Work-life balance is important to both the cities and the rural areas.

question: The number of advertisements for charities on television and the Internet seems to be increasing. What is causing this? Is this a positive or a negative development?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It indeed appears true that the frequency with which advertisements for charities appear both on television and the Internet seems to be increasing. There can be various explanations for this and it can be seen in both a positive and negative light.One explanation for the increase in the number of charity advertisements is that the charities themselves are becoming more aggressive in their marketing. This can also be seen in the common strategy nowadays to encourage a monthly donation, rather than a one-off donation. The increased marketing is apparent too in the increased numbers of ‘street salespeople’, who stop passersby and try to get them to commit to this monthly payment.A second reason for the increase could also be that there have been more charities started and the number of advertisements would therefore increase and become more noticeable. If these charities are all legitimate, this would mean that more help will be getting to causes that need it. The increase in charities could also be explained by a possible increase of humanitarian awareness. People might be now adopting different ideologies that take into account people in less advantageous positions.If the number of advertisements for charities has risen due to the fact that there has been a positive shift in people’s compassionate principles, this surely has to be seen as an optimistic development. If it is due to the fact that governments have been cutting back, it could be seen as a pessimistic development. In addition, if there are more charities asking for more money, this will inevitably mean that the amount of money donated will have to be more thinly spread, which would be a negative development.There could be several reasons for why there are more charity advertisements today. Whatever the reasons, as long as any money is helping people in disadvantageous positions, it must be seen as a positive development.
llm: An increasing number of charities are becoming more common on the Internet and on television. One reason is the increase in global challenges such as climate change, poverty and disease. This increase is caused by a number of factors such as the growing need for social awareness, technological development, and a change in people's values towards altruism. In addition, the digital transformation has provided charities with sophisticated marketing tools to reach out. As these challenges have become more pronounced, they are seeking to engage the public and raise awareness of the issues. For example, there are more campaigns for tackling homelessness or access to clean water, where organizations are looking for donations and volunteers. In this way, the increase in charities may be a positive development as it inspires people to take action and donate to good causes. However, it also has its disadvantages. Social media platforms and streaming services have democratized advertising, making it possible for even smaller organizations to reach a wider audience. In addition, the frequent bombardment of misery and despair can give rise to feelings of helplessness and numbness, instead of inspiring people to take action. In short, the increase in the number of advertisements for charities is largely caused by the urgent social need and the technological development. The most important thing for charities is to achieve a balance between being effective campaigners and maintaining the public's compassion. This balance is crucial to ensuring long-term support for the cause.

question: The picture below shows how a hot balloon works. Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The imagine illustrates how a hot balloon can fly in the sky and which parts is made of.In brief, a hot ballon is composed by a basket, burner where a flame is produced to heat cool air and an envelope connected to it by a skirt and ropes. Hot air is made in order to allow the hot ballon to work.Firstly, the basket welcomes people aboard. Meanwhile, ropes allow to connect the basket to the skirt and the envelope, which is composed by few panels in a vertical lane, multiple gores and a parachute valve. This one is a self-sealing flap that allows hot air to escape a controlled rate.Secondly, Between the skirt and the basket is located a burner which is crucial for the use of the hot balloon. In fact, it has got a propane cylinder that mix this gas with cool air so that ignites a flame to heat the air inside of the envelope. As a result hot air is made, which is lighter than cool air, and allows the hot ballon to fly in the sky.
llm: The diagram shows the functioning of a hot-air balloon and the interaction of its parts. The balloon is attached to the burner, an essential component under the envelope. It is an important feature of the balloon to have a opening on the envelope and a vent on top. The burner is the main source of heat, a flame produced by burning gas, which heats the air inside the balloon. The heated air expands, and, being less dense than the cooler air outside, creates a buoyancy that carries the balloon upwards. The balloon is connected to a basket or gondola that serves as a passenger compartment and houses the fuel tank for the burner. The vent is a source of hot air that can be let out, and which gives the pilot the opportunity to control the balloon's height. By letting out the hot air, the pilot can reduce altitude, and letting in the hot air again, he can increase lift. The combination of the burner, the heated air inside the envelope, and the control system allows the balloon to work effectively and provides the public with a unique and aesthetically pleasing experience of flight. The whole system is light in weight for maximum efficiency and stability, which allows controlled ascent and descent.

question: The picture below shows the plan of a museum in 1998 and after some changes were made in it in 2008. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.Write a report for a university lecturer describing the information shown below.

llm: In 1998, the museum was quite simple, divided into several sections. A careful comparison of the two plans reveals significant changes that improve the functionality and visitor experience of the museum. On the ground floor, there was a large exhibition hall, which was centered; the left side of the entrance led to the museum shop, and on the right side of the wing to the museum restaurant. On the first floor, the extension to the exhibition hall, and a small office, which was used for registration, were also located. The most significant change is that the exhibition hall was divided into two larger ones: exhibitions A and B. A new entrance was opened on the opposite side of the shop, thereby facilitating the entrance to the museum. Another significant change was the relocation of the restaurant. This made it possible to present a wider range of exhibitions. The office was also enlarged, which facilitated the work of museum employees. In general, the changes between 1998 and 2008 were significant and aimed at strategically improving the museum layout for visitors. Through these changes, the museum responded to the needs of visitors and thereby confirmed the importance of the development of public cultural institutions. The new design offers more opportunities for presenting expositions, more space for visitors and better amenities.

llm: In 1980, the park was a natural place with extensive grass and scattered trees, which represented the state of nature before the industrial revolution. Its development reflects the changes in social and environmental attitudes as well as changes in public recreation. The improvised paths and few benches showed a desire to emphasize nature rather than comfort, and few structures, such as a few benches and a small playground, showed a preference for nature over the usual amenities. The open space attracted visitors seeking simplicity and tranquility. Adding paved paths made the park more accessible to pedestrians and cyclists and showed the intention of accommodating a wider range of visitors. In contrast, the park today is a well-organized, multi-purpose place of recreation. The presence of more landscape features such as flowers and trees gives a more colorful, pleasant impression. The development of the park is a reflection of changes in the expectations of visitors, especially families and local residents, who want to see more amenities and recreation areas. This change not only serves the recreation needs of a new society but also reflects the desire to improve urban green spaces for community and environmental benefits. In short, the evolution of the park from the 1980s to the present shows how it has changed from a natural place to a multi-purpose recreation area.

question: The pie charts below show the percentage of housing owned and rented in the UK in 1991 and 2007.Summarize the information by describing the main features of the charts and making comparisons where appropriate.

llm: In 1991, the majority of housing was owned, with 66% of houses being occupied by the owner. The remaining 34% was made up of social and private rented housing. Then, in 2007, the number of private and social rented houses was almost the same as in 1991. However, the percentage of owner-occupied houses had fallen to 66%, while the number of houses rented out increased by 11%. This ownership structure reflects a stable housing market in which home ownership was seen as a sign of economic stability and its associated benefits. Interestingly, the percentage of social housing remained almost the same, indicating that, although the demand for private rental accommodation had increased, the availability of social housing remained fairly stable. The number of privately rented houses increased significantly, partly because the preferences of younger generations have changed in favour of mobility rather than the ties of home ownership. And the trend towards renting also reflects the growing acceptance of more diverse lifestyles and urban lifestyles as economic conditions have changed. In conclusion, a comparison of the two charts shows a shift in the UK housing market from a strong preference for owner-occupied housing towards a more balanced structure in which rental accommodation is more popular. This shift in the percentages shows wider socio-economic changes, such as changes in the population structure, changes in economic conditions and changing attitudes to home ownership and renting.

question: The process below shows how to make dough for a pizza.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: In the diagram, the steps needed to obtain a dough for a pizza are shown, figures are given for grams and time required for the process.In the initial stage, the staple ingredients, namely, 4 coup of 00 flour, 325 gr of water ( roughly one and a half cups) and a half teaspoon of dry active yeast respectively, are blended together in a cup.After being placed in a stand mixer, the primordial dough undergo through 3 mixing stages, with the first and the third at slow speed for 2 minutes each, and the second at medium speed for 5 minutes.Subsequently, the dough is going to be left to rest as long as its thickness has increased twofold, which it would takes at least 2 Hours.Having gotten rid of the bubbles by squeezing them manually, the resulting portion of dough is either divided thoroughly into 3 slices equally sized or making each of the three parts weigh 275 grams.
llm: The following process is quite simple, but is an essential part of making a delicious pizza. There are five key steps in the process. The ingredients are: flour, water, yeast, salt and olive oil. The flour is used to give the dough its structure and the water activates the yeast which is vital for fermentation. The salt strengthens the gluten, giving the dough its elasticity. The yeast is added to ensure that the mixture is not too dry. The olive oil adds moisture and flavour. This combination is crucial for the hydration of the flour and the development of the gluten. The flour and salt are gradually added to the water, which has been dissolved in it, to form a thick paste. This paste is then kneaded for about ten minutes. This step is essential as it ensures the development of the gluten, giving the dough its chewy texture. Once the kneading has been completed, the dough is left to rest and rise for about an hour. This is done in a warm place, as the yeast begins to produce the carbon dioxide which causes the dough to rise. Compared to other breads, the rising time is often shorter and the dough is less well hydrated, giving the finished product a denser, chewier texture. Finally, once the dough has doubled in size, it is ready to be shaped. This shaping can be done by hand or by using a rolling pin, depending on the thickness of the crust that is desired. Each of these steps contributes to the finished product, which is essential for the success of the whole dish. In conclusion, making a good pizza requires a simple but precise process which combines the right ingredients, the right mixture, kneading and rising times.

question: The proportion of older people is increasing, what problems will this cause and what solutions can be suggested?
human: In many countries the proportion of older people is steadily increasing. What problems will this cause for individuals and society? Suggest some measures that could be taken to reduce the impact of ageing populations.It is true that nowadays people in industrialised nations can expect to live longer than ever before. Although there will undoubtedly be some negative consequences to this trend, societies can take steps to mitigate these potential problems.As people live longer and the populations of developed countries grow older, several related problems can be anticipated. The main issue is that there will obviously be more people of retirement age who will be eligible to receive a pension. The proportion of younger, working adults will be smaller, and governments will therefore receive less money in taxes in relation to the size of the population. In other words, an ageing population will mean a greater tax burden working adults. Further pressures will include a rise in the demand for healthcare, and the adults will increasingly have to look after their elderly relatives.There are several actions that governments could take to solve the problems described above. Firstly, a simple solution would be to increase the retirement age for working adults, perhaps from 65 to 70. Nowadays, people of this age tend to be healthy enough to continue a productive working life. A second measure would be for governments to encourage immigration in order to increase the number of working adults who pay taxes. Finally, money from national budgets will need to be taken from other areas and spent vital healthcare, accommodation and transport facilities for the rising numbers of senior citizens.In conclusion, various measures can be taken to tackle the problems that are certain to arise as the populations of countries grow older.This essay covers the task requirements, however some problems of aging population get only a brief mention. The linking of sentences in the second body paragraph is somewhat ‘mechanical’ and could have been improved. Information sequencing and organisation in paragraphs are done well. The range of vocabulary and the fluency of its use, as well as lack of errors are impressive. Overall, this is a good example of how to get Band 8 without writing a very long essay.
llm: Life expectancy continues to increase due to advances in medicine and better living conditions, which means that the increasing proportion of older people in society should be critically analyzed and solved. One of the major problems with an aging population is the burden it places on health care. The economy is also significantly affected by an increasing proportion of elderly people. The care of older people who often need more health care and more chronic disease care leads to an increased demand for health care professionals and material. This in turn leads to increased waiting times, reduced access to health care and increased health care costs for both individuals and governments. In many countries it will be difficult for governments to set aside enough funds for pensions and care for the elderly, and the younger generations will be put under great financial pressure. To cope with these challenges, there are several solutions that can be used. Firstly, it can be alleviated by promoting an active aging with policies that make it possible for older people to stay in the labor market longer, by facilitating flexible work hours, by retraining and by tax incentives for companies to hire older people. Secondly, preventive health care and health care in the community can relieve health care systems. Thirdly, intergenerational cooperation can strengthen social cohesion and share knowledge, perspectives and resources between the generations. - Regular examinations, health education and healthy lifestyles can help reduce the onset of chronic diseases.

question: The table below gives information about the population of New Zealand between 2011 and 2012.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and making comparisons where relevant.
human: The table details the number of people living in New Zealand changed from2011 to 2012 and divided those people into four age groups.Looking from an overall perspective, the number of all ages was increasing. However, the percentage change in those four devided age groups was not as same as the all ages, to the contrary, two of these groups just showed opposite trend.In terms of all ages, the number in 2012 was 4,460,000, compared to the number in 2011, the percentage change increased 0,6 , which was as same as the percentage change of the 40-64 age group. Besides, we can easily see that the change in 65+ group was the most significant one, with the figure in 2011 500,000, increased 400,000, approximately double in the following year.As for the two decending age groups, under 15 and 15-39, the percentage change were both -0,2 , although the specific numbers were different. The age under 15 amounted to 801,750, was merely declined 1,750 in 2012, at the same time, the number of 15-39 group was largely decreased, changed from 1,520,000 to 1.500,000 in 2012.
llm: In 2011, the population of New Zealand was about 4.3 million people. The table shows the population of New Zealand for two years and reveals changes in the distribution of the population across the age groups. The table also shows the level of population growth and decline in these two years. Interestingly, the percentage of people aged 60 and over was significantly lower, about 14%. The largest age group was people aged 15-29, with about 20% of the population, and the next most numerous was those aged 30-44, with about 19%. The most noticeable change occurred in the age distribution towards the oldest group: the percentage of people over 60 rose to 16%, indicating a gradual aging of the population. By the end of 2012, the population increased to about 4.5 million, and the percentage of people over 60 rose to 17%, which suggests a gradual increase in the population. Another comparison is the balance of young and old people. The percentage of people aged 15-29 and 30-44 fell slightly to 19% and 18% respectively. This may indicate that the population of young people is not growing as quickly as the population of older people. The data indicate that the population is steadily aging, which may be a reflection of changing societal structures. The increase in the older population is a reflection of New Zealand's trend towards longer life and higher life expectancy, while the slight decline in the young population can be attributed to migration and changes in birth rates.

question: The table below gives information about the underground railway systems in six cities.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The given table provides dataset on subway systems in 6 different cities in 3 different cities in 3 distinctive continents. The figures are displayed in terms of inauguration date, the length of route, in kilometers, and number of passengers in millions.Overall, the table outlines that older systems also are longer in extension and have more passengers.London, Paris and Tokyo were opened before the first half of the twentieth century (1863, 1900 and 1927 respectively). The former has the longest route (394 km) and latter the shortest (155 km); on the other hand the Japanese city has almost three times more passengers than the English capital.The cities with younger systems, namely Washington DC, Kyoto and Los Angeles were all opened after 1970. The North American cities have respectively 126 km and 28 km; while the Asian city accounts for 11 km. The capital of the US has the highest number of passengers (144 million) and the Asian city, the shortest, 45 million.
llm: The table shows information about six cities, London, Paris, New York, Tokyo, Washington, D.C., and Los Angeles. London is the oldest underground railway, opened in 1863. In length, Tokyo is much longer than other underground systems, with 368 kilometers. Los Angeles, on the other hand, is the newest. The difference in age between these two is a reflection of the difference in the stage of urban development and public transport. Paris and Tokyo have the highest annual use figures, respectively, of 1,189 million and 3,927 million passengers. This reflects their widespread use and the way in which they are integrated into daily life. London comes second with 402 kilometers, while Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles have the shortest lines, respectively, 126 and 28 kilometers. In the end, it is clear that Tokyo and Paris have established very long underground railway systems and are heavily used, while Los Angeles has the shortest. Despite its relatively long length, London carries 1,350 million passengers annually, indicating the competitivity of urban transport in these cities. Washington D.C. and Los Angeles have the shortest line and the lowest passenger number, respectively, 144 million and 50 million. This may reflect the fact that the car is more popular than public transport, or that the system is not so connected to other cities in the world. The data shows that urban rail transport plays a vital role in the public transport of these cities.

question: The table below shows social and economic indicators for four countries in 1994, according to United Nations statistics.Describe the information shown below in your own words. What implications do the indicators have for the countries?
human: The table compares the performance of social and economic aspects for Canada, Japan, Peru and Zaire in 1995. People in Peru and Zaire earned a lower annual income, almost 98 times less than people in Canada and Japan.With regard to the social indicators, people in Canada and Japan showed a longer life expectancy at birth, both of which had a life expectancy of more than 75 years old, whereas the life expectancy in Peru and Zaire was much lower, with only around 50 years old. The adult literacy rate in Canada and Japan saw the same percentage, both at 99%. While 68% of adults in Peru had literacy, the adult literacy rate in Zaire was only 34%, two times less than Peru and almost three times lower than Canada and Japan. With respect to the daily calorie supply, Canada had the highest calorie supply per person, with a number of 3326, while Japan, Peru, and Zaire received a lower calorie supply with aroud 2000 only.
llm: When examining the differences in per capita income between the countries, the disparity is clearly visible. Looking at life expectancy and literacy, it can be seen that there is a wide difference in the life and living conditions of the population. Life expectancy is another indicator of the state of health in each country. Higher per capita income suggests greater wealth and productivity and a greater likelihood of spending on health, education and social security. The literacy rate adds further information on social development. Higher life expectancy is associated with better public health, standards of hygiene and living conditions. However, countries with low literacy rates have fewer opportunities for education, employment and development. A high level of literacy suggests a well-educated workforce and, by implication, a more prosperous and capable population. These disparities between countries and between their citizens need to be addressed if social and economic development is to be achieved.
